Oshkosh. Apr. 8th "88. Dear Mother. Your letter rec'd. Thursday: with the two checks and the money order. Well I went to the bank and got the check's cashed. - and from there went to the P.O. to get the money on the Order: but they would not let me have it: as the P.M. there at Bainbridge had made a mistake: and got my name written Arnes. - instead of Arno. Well the clerk here wrote right back to the P.M. there, and told me to will pay that the unclear of April. I shall write to him tonight. With Love and a Kiss I will say good bye. Your loving daughter, Mary Arno, Oshkosh, Wis.

come down the 9th, or 10th, as he would have word from him by that time, It will be all right; for it is only a mistake and will be rectified. As soon as I get it, I will pay it to Mr. Bray on the mortgage: and $10.00 more with it from the rent; which will make $96.00 I won't take the dollar now as I want to pay him as much as I can. Just as much obliged to you all the same. I will be glad when it is all paid. Wont you? I had $10.00 from my place in D.T. besides paying the taxes; but I'm not discouraged: for

there was only two acres of it in crops this last year: and this year it is all rented. Mr. Mayberry has 10 acres to put in on shares; I have 1/3
and Mr. Johnson will take the 50 acres at 75 cts. per acre. I will have at least $50.00 from it besides the Taxes. That is 10% on on the money
I invested. Don't you think that pretty good. Mr. Gunderson has the hay on any place in Minn. for two years for paying the taxes.Your house
here in Oshkosh is rented to the same family it was. and your place in Branden

is rented for $2.00 a month. Your place here is insured for $150.00 that is all they would insure it for. You asked about Aunt Susan: I had a letter from Aunt Mary and she said they heard she could sit up some now. It was a fever that ailed her: intermittently caused by her worrying and fretting over $100.00 that Geo. A. Russell cheated her out of. I think she will get well now - if she can sit up. Mr. Cheney is dead: of Cheney's Corners. - you know who I mean apart. I hope it wont be busy. Well I must close now. With love to you I will say good bye. You write and let me know how you are getting along. I expect to hear from Geo. every day he said he would pay that the unclear April I shall

don't you? also Mr. Pinkerton the one that lived near Ladoya. Sarah Smith Tuttle: she that was Sarah Smith: Allen Smiths daughter. had a stroke of paralysis and the lower portion of her body is perfectly useless: the Dr. think there is no hopes of her recovery. Of course you remember Willie Morris. - he was buried the other day. He died of brain fever. I didn't know that he had been sick until he was dead. unclear folks sold their old place & built a new house on the same there. do they pay you anything. let me know when you write. I have worried so much about you: you cant imagine. I am glad you have not forgotten me. I think of you so often & wonder how much longer have got to this

I was sorry I couldn't send you unclear little birthday present but perhaps it wont be always thus. this fall I will get you something nice. I am glad you have a nice place street; first one lot this side of Jackson St., They  have a splendid place. Oh! Mrs. Jones has another pair of twins. - This makes three pair she has had right along. Dont that unclear the unclear. They live where Catherine's folks used to. - her Mother has bought that place. & Mrs. Jones has it when they are through with it. Effie Ford is married, and got a little girl Mr. Clark has torn down his old house and is going to put up a fine building on that corner. wont that be nice. I hope when we move again it will be in our own house

Oshkosh. June 6th. "88. Dear Mother. - I received the box today: it came all right but that cracker concern: & I couldnt tell what it was meant for: it was so crumbled. The sugar was splendid. & that trimming I will have on a pair of drawers right away. Oh! I've been so lonesome ever since I got that box there - I can't hardly contain unclear so when you get this: write me a good long letter Are you staying at Mr. Bills yet. Let me know what you are doing at Unadiller?. Who lives there that you know. How is Grandpa. - have you seen him lately and what of Uncle Emery's folks.

myself. My health is so miserable  that I think sometime I shall  unclear see you again.- this living up stairs business is just killing me; and again: I think, you don't care if you never see me again. - I love you with all my heart: and only wish I could see you tonight. When I think you care more for someone else than you do you for me: it almost drives me crazy. There is no one on Earth that I think as much of as I do of you. You don't write to me any more. - or not often: and only

a few times in regard ] to business; but I shall write to you as long as I can. Your house here is rented for $6.00 - Those folks paid their rent all right - I'm going to get the paint Saturday for them to paint the floor. I have a new dress and as soon as it is finished will have some pictures taken. Won't you have some taken &  send me one. I will pay for them if you will have them taken. Lester Slevins was here to to see me yesterday. he was out to D. T last fall

surveying. - he says I wouldn't know Redfield. - its is such a large place. He says land around there is worth something. He is going out again the 20th of July. - and from there is going to Cal. to be gone three years. Oh! I had a letter from Henry Brown last Winter. - he is in Colorado, he directed the letter. - Miss Olivia Hurd. - he didn't know that I was married. Daniel - Elda Arnold today. - she is growing up to be a beautiful girl just as handsome as a doll. - and so nice: anyone couldn't help but like her; don't you? I must not write anymore tonight so when you get this write me

when I got your letter that time with that verse in. - it was to late to send it. What did you draw as a prayer. Tell me when you write. - or didn't you get anything. When you send your pension I will finish paying up that mortgage. and as soon as I get the money will pay what I owe you. I have written to Mr. Lamb that I wanted some money this fall: and when I get it will pay it right to Mr. Bray. - and also pay the $46.00 I owe Mr. Schroeder on

my lord?. I shall be so glad when I'm out of debt. Well Ma: do write to me when you get this: for I'm so lonesome: it seems as if I should die. 
With a fond kiss. - I will bid you good night Your loving Daughter. Mary Oshkosh. Wis.

Oshkosh. July. 21st. '88. Dear Mother. Your postal rec'd. yesterday, and will write a few lines. I have been down to Brandon. - when I got there 
found Aunt Mary sick abed, but: she is up and around now. Aunt Susan can't last much longer. - she fails all the time. How are you getting
along anyway. - I feel quite well just then for me. When you write to me: you write such short letters. What are you doing down to unclear?
Are you working. - Why didn't you stay at Mr. Bills longer.

Didn't you like there. I just got your insurance policy on your house here yesterday. It is insured for $273.00 for three years. I wanted a little money to use:  and I took $ 2.00 out of your rent - do your care. Eva Tinkhaur? is dead. Mrs. Fords daughter's child. You remember her don't you. She was only sick in bed four days. Walter Oakes & Maude Lee Fever were married last Tuesday. - Walter sent us an announcement of the affair. Dave got me a new white dress this Summer. It is pretty. Do. you intend to give me that lot on Vine St., if

so let me know. for if you do: will set out a strawberry bed in Aug. I have written to Mayberry if he knows of anyone that wants to buy an 80 of land there. - and if he does to tell them one of my 80 is for sale. - If I sell I shall take part of the money and build me a house, I wont live in a
rented house much longer. It is just killing me. I must not stop to write much more this time: for I have got to go to town. Write a good long 
letter & where I write again I will do the same. With Love and a kiss I will say good bye.
Now write as soon as you get this. Your affectionate Daughter Mary. Direct Oshkosh. Wis.

Oshkosh. Oct 10th 88. Dear Mother Your letter rec'd. Saturday night; and will write so you will get this Sat. if not before. I was glad to hear from you: as I always am. We are having bright weather: but quite cold. It freezes some every night. I have been gathering hickory nuts all
this week so far: I have in all about 28 quarts. the man that lives on Tom Wall's place said I could gather all I wanted, so I'm going to see how many I can get. Mr. Spragues folks were up Sunday and I had a nice time. I like them very much. didn't you

what little you got acquainted with them. I'm going down town today hopeing to hear from Mr. Lamb in regard to potatoes. I wrote him some time ago: but have not heard from him yet. Potatoes are very high. they are 35 to 40 cts. per bu. and will be still higher before Spring. -  if I don't hear from Mr. L today: we will get our potatoes for Winter. - I have ordered my onions & turnips. and got 14 heads of cabbage: which I will make into sauer-kraut: and get more for Winter use. As soon as it gets a little cooler: we will get half a hog & a quarter of beef and we will be fixed for Winter. Dave has done fine this Summer: he has got $2.00 a day right. along and is still getting that price.

He is very different to me than he used to be. - when he found out he couldnt have everything his own way it made a different man of him. He works hard. and has done fine this Summer: as he has worked by the day the most of the time: which is far better: then working by the job. I shant try to do my washings this Winter. I can get it done cheaper that I can do it. Yes, your house is rented in Brandon: I get $2.00 a month for it: Mr. Lamphers? folks live in it: a Brother of Allie's Father. Did you know Allie was married. - she married Harvey Randall. - & Lizzie Yooty? married Frank Randall. Frank is Telegraph operator at Tulare D. T. - only 12 miles from

my place in D.T. In regard to that money I paid Mr. Bray. - I paid the mortgage up: & took the note: and he said he would have the mortgage cancelled the first time he went to the court house. I haven't seen him since: but when I do will speak to him about it. - he isn't that kind of a man to forget anything. The mortgage wouldn't be of any account with out the note anyway. If I should see him on the street today: will speak to him about it. Root are the folks names that live down stairs. I don't like her: so have never been in the house but two or three

5th. times all Summer. Ma. you couldn't of got all my letters: for in one I wrote that Clarke was building a new house. also that Willie Morris was dead. Aunt Susan is getting some better: when I go down again I shall go and see her. Mrs. Linda has a cancer. - they say she can't live very long. Mrs. Lamb has a little boy: he is about five weeks old. Rosa Acker Sizer? has a little boy. - so she has got two now. - a girl & boy. Do you take the Brandon Times. - tell me when you write. Miles Smith is married to Etta Starbird. You remember Ida Kelley - don't you. - R. C. Kelleys adopted daughter. she is a wild

thing. one night. this Summer Mr. & Mrs. K went to Church & left Ida at home: & when they went home: couldn't find anything of her until the next day; & then where do you suppose they found her. Over to the "Bluff", (or what used to be: but called Utley now:) with about 30 men. They sent her to the house of correction at Waukesha: and later Mr. & Mrs. K - started for York State on a visit and on their way stopped to see Ida. - she begged so hard to be taken out - : that they took her out. and I havent heard any thing about her since. I guess that subdued her a little. When you write tell what Grace wrote out there. about our being down there this last Winter. Where did Mr. B

write to you. - If I was in your place I shouldn't write to him: you will be sorry you ever did some day. Since he got that pension he swings very high. What is Nellies name now. I  forgot: I should unclear - take care of themselves: & we will do the same. and in the long run: see who has the nicest home. I bet we will come out ahead. Write and tell me just what you think: dont be afraid to write just as you would talk. for I burn your letters as soon as I read them. No one ever reads a word you write. & burn my letters as soon as read. Yes. I want your picture: have it taken right way: and send me one. I will have some taken

this Fall I think. You must surely come home another Summer: for I want to see you so much. Do you ever think of me. I often wonder if you do? I must draw this news paper to a close. I guess you will think you have a good long letter - by the time you have this read this through. Now write so I will get a letter sometime next week. I shall look for one Thursday - sure. With Love & a kiss I will close. You loving Daughter. 
Mary Arno. Oshkosh Wis I will send some papers with this. Good bye Write soon.

Oshkosh. Nov. 20th. '88. Dear Mother. - Your letter received a few days ago: and as I'm going down town will write so as take it. I have been very busy of late cleaning houses and fixing up for Winter. I'm not all through with my cleaning yet for Dan is going to cut a door from the bedroom into the kitchen - won't that be nice. Then it will always be warm without building a fire in the front room. Dan has work all the time now at $1.50 per day. - That is good these short days. - don't you think so. We have our wood for Winter I must not write any more this time as it is getting late: & I want to get home at noon. Dan takes his dinner so I have all day to myself. I want you to have your picture taken & send to me. - will you. With Love and a kiss I will say good bye. - Mary.

also vegatables: and as  soon as it gets a little colder: will get our meat. and as for clothes we are very comfortable. Dan got him a new suit of clothes this Summer and a new over coat & hat this fall. and I have a new flannel dress. it is very pretty; with a goblin blue velvet front - a new
pair of shoes & hat: and plenty under clothes. You bet when we go any where we look just as good as the next one. - including the Barden's -  and they think they are about right. I have got to go today and order another load of saw dust to finish banking your house. I got two loads & it 
needs another and a few more boards. The folks wouldnt stay unless I banked it: and covered unclear I dont know. Write as soon as you get this

the cistern so it wouldnt freeze. It wont cost more than $2.50 and then we will have the saw dust to bank again with. They are nice folks: and very likely will stay for years. for they like it here. Brandon was almost all burnt down last week. the business portion. - it was set afire. - they will burn it all up before they quit. Your house is all right yet. I'm afraid it will never be built up again. I've going down before long: to see how it looks. Snow is holding off remarkable well: we had a little unclear: but it soon wore off. - This is a lovely day. - I'm going to wash when I get back from town. Was you acquainted with John Van Ness. - if you wasn't Write soon and write a good long letter. Where are you going Thanksgiving - I guess we will say at home

acquainted with him you very likely heard him spoken of. - he took his family out to Iowa and was killed there. - I had a letter from Aunt Mary saying Uncle John had gone to Waupun for one of the pall bearers. - how he was killed they did not know. Lucy Lockwood's husband is dead in Brandon. Mrs. Linde was buried about two weeks ago. Thus - one by one: the old settlers go. They say Aunt Susan is getting some better. She has been sick over a year. I'm as fat as a pig you would hardly know me. I'm going to have some pictures taken before long. Yes. - I hope we will have a nice house. The next time I write I will send you my plan and you tell me how you like it. You let them hire the washing done: if you don't give but $1.50 per week for it is too cold work for it in Winter. I shall hire mine done. I must not write
SKHO? MAR 18? Mrs. Augusta Hurd. Unadilla. New York.

Oshkosh. Jan 11th. '89. Dear Mother. - Your postal rec'd a day or so ago: and will answer it tonight. We went down to Brandon and staid a little over a week. had a splendid time. on our way home: we stopped at Rosendale. - to Dan's Uncle - We also had a nice time there. Aunt Mary is not feeling very well: her heart bothers her a great deal. We got home last Monday - and have staid every night with Mrs. Ford since: as she is above. Dan has done the chores for her lately. - as the snow is so deep I won't write any more tonight so I will say good bye From your loving girl Mary - Now write soon and a good long letter. Uncle Chas. is over to Aunt Susans. - When he got his Dec. pension he gambled it all away.

We have just had a terrible snow storm. the worst one we have had this Winter. The snow is 20 inches on the level. I was glad we got home: for I would had the blues down to Rosendale. had I been there You asked what I got for Christmas. Uncle John gave me cloth for two aprons. & Aunt Mary gave us a lot of butter. I will send you your present in a few days. Excuse the delay. I shall be so glad when we get a house of our own. This paying rent isnt what I relish very much. I will draw a plan of a house Sunday and send you so you will get it next week. I shall expect a letter by Sat. night sure. Love & a kiss O Good night

I want to see you so bad I don't know what to do - I bet when you come back we will never be apart again. Mr. Mayberry is in Pa. visiting this Winter. I had a letter from him yesterday. I will pay your taxes the 18th of this month. Ma. I'm fat as a pig. I don't believe you would hardly know me. - I'm going to have some Cabinet pictures taken before long. will send you one. Send me your picture I will be so glad when you come. The folks are in your house yet - they are splendid folks. I think. I think $1.50 per week & hire the washing done is quite he would be better off without any at all - now write soon.

good pay - Dan hasnt any work at present: but I think will get a job soon - We are well fixed for the Winter. Ma. I tell you what I'm going to do with Mr. Lamb in the Spring. - put a chattle mortgage on his crop. for I cant get a cent with out. He promised me surely he would pay me $30.00 this fall. - but cant get one cent. - So I might as well have his crop as to have someone else have it. - Did you know Maude Knapp. - she is dead. She married a man by the name of Jones. She left a little baby a few days old. Aunt Susan is able to go out and eat with the rest now. I'm willing for it isn't very likely I will go there very soon. - I think Aunt S. is as bad as Amelia I wont write any

Write as soon as you get this. - Ever your Loving Girl. Mary Good bye. A kiss O. another this season. I might as well get something as for Chase to get it all. Oshkosh. Jan 31st. "89. Dear Mother - I wrote to you ever so long ago: but do not hear a word. - I fear you are sick. When you get this answer immediately for I'm anxious to hear how you are. We are having a beautiful Winter. - the coldest it has ever been is 3 degrees below zero. It stormed a little last night but is as clear as a bell today. It is almost Spring. and I'm not sorry for then Dan will have work. He worked all the time until just Christmas since then he hasnt had much to do. We are getting along nicely.

and have $20.00 to keep us on until Spring. I tell you what it seems good not to run a bill. I paid your taxes the other day. They were $10.50 Taxes are very high here. - Mrs. Ford has to pay $90.50 and sold over twelve acres of her land last Spring. I had a letter from Hermandsen. - He says there is a man that wants to rent your land. - (A man that has bought the Frost place.) but he want to rent some land besides. The man wants to rent it for a number of years. - but Mr. Hermandsen didnt think he would be willing to pay anything the first year: for it has grown up to

grass and he will have to pay as much as it is worth to get it broke. - Shall I tell him he can have it the first year for paying the taxes. - and the next two years for $100.00 a year & he pay the taxes. I think that cheap enough. - but before I would have it stand idle: I would rent it for less. If he will take it: I will have the contract made out for three years. I wouldnt rent it for any longer time then that. Now let me know about this at once: as the man wants to know right away. Did Hermandsen have the grass this last year for paying the taxes.

A hundred dollars a year and he pay the taxes seems cheap so for 80 acres of land: but we better take that then nothing. (Be sure and write as soon as you get this.) I will write to Mr. Ostander and ask him how much he thinks it ought to rent for: - he will know more about it then we do. and how much the man ought to pay the first year. If I was in your place I would rent it at some price and if you will let me me have the renting of it: I will get all I can. Mr. Lamb sent us 17 bu. of potatoes: & all were frozen but 6 bu. wasnt that a shame. He will have to loose them we won't. The next time I go to Brandon I'm going to tell him I will have to have security on his crops this season. I might as well

Feb, 26th 89 Dear Mother, You go to the express office if you don't recieve a package by mail as I will send one today. I will send it the cheapest way. In haste, Your Loving Daughter Mary You are all unclear birthday unclear Later. - Sent it - by Express.

Oshkosh. March 16th. "89. Dear Mother - I received a letter from you this morning: also one from Mr. Hermandsen and tell him the man can have it this year for paying the taxes and $25.00 besides. - but if we can't get the $25.00 extra: I should let him have mood - by the way this letter hangs on. Mr. & Mrs. Linde are both dead. - Also Jack Hall's wife in Brandon. Fred Fister? has bought the land where Ferguson's folks had their store. - in fact the north side of the street. - & he is going to build it up with brick this Spring. He has all the brick hauled.

it for paying the taxes: for next year you would have $200.00 from it, and $200.00 doesn't grow on every bush. Don't delay a minute in answering this; so I can let him know. - & if he takes it; I will have a contract made out and the rent to be paid in advance. for you see the $200.00 put out for one year would bring $16.00 enough to pay your taxes: & you would have the $200.00 besides. I presume if you don't let
it to this man: you will not have another chance: and it doesn't pay to have it idle. Oh! I'm so sorry you didn't get that box; I calculated it to get there your birthday. I shall go down and see then Now, Ma, write by return mail. You will get this Tuesday & I ought to have a letter back Thursday & if I wrote to Hermandsen then he would get it Saturday. With Love & a kiss. I will say good bye.

about it tonight. I sent cloth for a gingham dress. cloth for a white apron. - a white handkerchief. - and a white silk one. - If they are lost they will have to make them good. I'm going to have some pictures taken as soon as I get a new dress. and that will be before long. Do you remember Wilson's folks on Ohr? St. - Sam Wilson's folks. Well: the old lady was buried Thursday: & the youngest girl was buried the Thursday before. They now live on N.Y. Av. - where Ostrander's folks used to live. They bought that place. Nellie Barden lives on Pearl St. - I wonder what was the rip: that they didnt live at home. When I see Mr. Art. unclear is married to Lou. unclear. - They will live at La unclear D.T.

B - his is so high toned: he hardly speaks. - but I can not: for I consider we have as much to be proud of as they have: & a good deal more. I am working on plans of houses. - but havent decided on any yet: I want to consider the matter well: so I will be suited when the time comes. Do you hear from unclear. - He and Old Clark are Chums: and if I was in your place I would never speak to him again. For you know Clark is the worst old black-guard that ever lived. - and very likely he sides in with him. - As near as I can find out. the whole family are as deceitful as the day is long. - pretend to be your friend when in reality are nothing but back biters. - They are friends as long as your money lasts. - and when it is gone. - look out. Much obliged for the grapes. I guess you think I'm

Oshkosh. March, 18th 89 - Dear Mother I sent a letter Today, saying what was in that package. I have just found out my mistake. I directed it to Bainbridge instead of Unadilla. Perhaps you can have the express man there get it for you. I thought as much as could be I directed it to Unadilla. Now unclear it over & let me know about that

land business. I have $25.00 from the rent & am going to borrow enough to pay up on my land in D. T. - I suppose you know Dakota is divided!
I think the Capital will be at Huron. if so. - my place will only be only 40 miles from it.  Write at once dont delay. - Let me know if you get the things. Your girl, Mary.

Oshkosh June 5th. 89 Dear Mother.  I recd. your letter a day or so ago. it found me well: but in great trouble. I recd. my papers. from Mr. Schroeder all right and all I lacked was the patent so I wrote to Huron to see if it had come yet. - and the answer I recd. was: that my claim had been cancelled; after that I must make new proof with in 60 days. - or I would forfeit all night all right. It stated the complaint was for want of improvement that all I had was 6 acres of breaking. - I went to

Bouck & Hilton - and they said I would have to go there. that all the trouble arose from some villian who was trying to steal it away from me. I am going to get $50.00 of Bray today if I can and if I get it will start Friday morning. I will drop you a line when I start and as soon as I get there. - You said you would send $50.00 for me to pay Mr. Bray. - I presume I shall have to have it: so send it to Redfield. Hilton told me to go to Mr. Schriber of the National Bank and get a recommend from him to some good Lawyer in Redfield. He said

it would help me a great deal. If I find out who it is that is trying to get my claim. - I will publish him as sure as I live. I half believe it is Geo. or Uncle Dan - I don't think either are any too good to do it. Do you? With Love I will say good bye. - Later. I got $50.00 of Mr. Bray. - and promised to pay it back as soon as you send it. So be sure and send $50.00 and more if you can. - at Redfield, D.T. Send by Money Order.
